title: How would you calculate the relative abundance for two isotopes when the relative atomic mass is given? - Quora

response.answer_text: The relative atomic mass is a weighted arithmetic mean. Let’s assume that the element [math]X[/math] consists of only two isotopes with the nuclide numbers [math]Y[/math] and [math]Z[/math]. If the atomic masses [math]M({}^YX)[/math] and [math]M({}^ZX)[/math] of the two isotopes [math]{}^YX[/math] and [math]{}^ZX[/math] are known, the relative (natural) abundances [math]NA({}^YX)[/math] and [math]NA({}^ZX)[/math] can be calculated from the relative atomic mass [math]\overline M(X)[/math]. [math]NA({}^YX)\times M({}^YX)+NA({}^ZX)\times M({}^ZX)=\overline M(X)[/math] [math]NA({}^YX)+NA({}^ZX)=1[/math] [math]NA({}^ZX)=1-NA({}^YX)[/math] [math]NA({}^YX)\times M({}^YX)+[1-NA({}^YX)]\times M({}^ZX)=\overline M(X)[/math] Solve for [math]NA({}^YX)[/math]. [math]NA({}^YX)=\frac{\overline M(X)-M({}^ZX)}{M({}^YX)-M({}^ZX)}[/math] The result is a number between 0 and 1. You can multiply by 100% to get percentages. [math]NA({}^YX)\text{%}=\frac{\overline M(X)-M({}^ZX)}{M({}^YX)-M({}^ZX)}\times 100\text{%}[/math] Take away this number from 100% to get the other abundance. [math]NA({}^ZX)\text{%}=100\text{%}-NA({}^YX)\text{%}[/math]

It is not difficult when only 2 isotopes are involved. Take for example, the element boron, the core of my Ph.D. thesis. Boron has 2 stable isotopes, B-10 and B-11. To a first approximation, B-10 has 10 amu and B-11 has 11 amu. The average atomic weight for B is 10.811. Relative abundances for B-10 and B-11 would be 20% and 80%, respectively.
